Articles.Content:
Background

At long last, after years of back and forth wrangling over which snacks to pack, the kerbals have nearly completed assembly of Space Station Sanguine, an observation platform for studying the wilds of Kerbin's mysterious northern hemisphere from orbit. Four days ago, Bob and his sidekick Cormund Kerman broke the seal on the station and became its first crew. They've spent the time preparing the station for its scientific mission and bickering over who gets to use the telescopes in the observation module.

Now, it's time to complete the construction of the station by installing the Plasma Operations Weightless Experimental Research (POWER) lab. This lab is intended to study fusion technologies in micro-gravity for possible future applications in space exploration. Additionally, the station needs four additional crew members who can run some of the other experiments and bring Bob his morning coffee.

Sanguine is in a Molniya orbit; a highly inclined, highly elliptical orbit over Kerbin, which "dwells" over Kerbin's northern hemisphere for 1.5 hours or so twice every Kerbin day. This orbit is semi-synchronous; it orbits exactly twice a day, passing over the same geographic features on Kerbin every other orbit.

The Kerbin Shuttle Orbiter Super 25 space vessel newly christened Ascension is fueled and ready on the launch pad at KSC. And Jeb and Bill are standing by to co-command. Your mission, should you choose to accept it, is to launch the final assembly mission to Sanguine: deliver the POWER lab to the station and transfer its remaining first crew complement. Then, de-orbit and land Ascension safely back on the runway at KSC.

Instructions

This is a piloting challenge, not a construction challenge. In fact, all VAB/SPH functions have been disabled in the scenario. The only vessels you'll need to complete the challenge are ready and waiting in the scenario. Ascension has plenty of fuel to complete the mission, provided you fly it efficiently. (In fact, Ascension may have too much fuel; I may reduce it if the challenge proves not high enough.)

DOWNLOAD HERE

To install, unzip the zip file to your KSP directory, (not your GameData directory.) Then, to run the scenario, start up KSP, choose Start Game, then Scenarios, then choose the Molniya Challenge from the list.

Note that saves and loads in scenarios are separate from saves and loads in the normal game. So you will not be able to load scenario saves from a normal game. This includes saves with Alt+F5. In order to load a scenario save, you must re-enter the scenario by choosing Start Game->Scenarios->Molniya Challenge from the main menu, then clicking the Continue button. Once the scenario has loaded, you'll have normal F9/Alt+F9 access to your saves.

You will need to perform the following actions to complete the challenge:

  1. Launch Ascension to orbit.
  2. Rendezvous with Sanguine and dock at the Shuttle Docking Port.
  3. Release the POWER lab from the shuttle's cargo bay. (It may be easier to do this before docking.)
  4. Use Sanguine's Orbital Tug to dock the POWER module to its intended location on Sanguine. (You will have to EVA a crew member to the tug before undocking it from Sanguine.)
  5. Transfer the four new crew members from Ascension to Sanguine using EVA. (Leave Jeb and Bill to pilot it home.)
  6. Undock Ascension and perform a de-orbiting burn.
  7. Re-enter Kerbin's atmosphere and land safely back at KSC.

Required Mods

  • Active Texture Management Release 3-3-1. [thread=59005]|thread|[/thread] Required to make KSO work.
  • Kerbin Shuttle Orbiter v3.10 |download| [thread=68429]|thread|[/thread] (There is a flight manual included with the v3.09 download that you may find useful if you haven't flown the KSO before.)
    Note that KSO requires running the 32-bit version of KSP. It does not run reliably with the 64-bit client.

Prohibited Mods

  • MechJeb - I'm fairly certain that MechJeb (which makes the mission pretty trivial) cannot be installed onto the vessels in the scenario without config editing, but as a note, MechJeb is not permitted for this challenge (much as I love it.)
  • FAR, NEAR, DREC - I don't think the mission is possible with these mods installed. Maybe if someone does complete it with them, I'll add an achievement for this.

Suggested Mods

  • NavyFish's Docking Port Alignment Indicator. |download| [thread=43901]|thread|[/thread] The important docking ports in the mission are named so that they can easily selected using the DPAI.
  • kujuman's NavUtilities with HSI. |download| [thread=85353]|thread|[/thread] This makes landing much easier. (Note that NavUtilities in exterior (non-IVA) view requires blizzy78's Toolbar [thread=60863]|thread|[/thread].)

Achievements

  • Safe and Sound - Complete the challenge with no loss of kerbal life.
  • Ready for Recovery - Complete the challenge with no vessel damage.
  • Two Point Landing - Land on the runway at KSC
  • Don't Worry, Be Happy - Land on the island runway (This may actually be easier than landing at KSC)
  • Like the Real Thing - Land Ascension completely unpowered, without using engines after the de-orbit burn. (There is an empty fuel tank at Sanguine that you can use to dump extra fuel while docked.)
  • Look Ma, No Eyes - Use only IVA and Map views to complete the mission

Hall of Fame

  • Mr Shifty, Mission completed - Day 6 01:37:29 UT, Achievements - Safe and Sound, Ready for Recovery, Two-Point Landing

Forthcoming

I have performed every step of the mission (though not all at once) and can verify that it is possible. I spent several hours making sure there was enough fuel to finish. Please let me know if you discover any problems with the scenario.

Have fun!

Edited March 14, 2018 by Mr Shifty
Fixed all the apostrphes and quotes after the forum upgrade messed them up

The impetus for this challenge was that because none of the planets or moons in KSP have any axial tilt, there's very little incentive to rendezvous with a station or other vessel in an inclined orbit. In real life, many visitable vessels in LEO (e.g. the ISS) are at fairly inclined orbits, and the fact that Earth's rotation is inclined to the ecliptic also means launches to inclined orbits, for example, for lunar transfers. Rendezvousing with a highly inclined orbit means that you not only have to match the target's inclination, but also its LAN (longitude of the ascending node) and so can only launch (efficiently) twice a day, with different launch headings for the two launch windows. And an eccentric orbit provides an additional interesting challenge for rendezvous, which I thought might be fun.

The Molniya orbit not only has the requisite inclination and eccentricity, but also is semi-synchronous, which provides an interesting problem with regard to direct re-entry, because there are only a limited possible range of landing sites. (Only two possible sites on the equator.) I had to adjust the orbit's LAN carefully to ensure that landing at KSC was feasible.

Alas, I was also enamored of the KSO add-on. It's got a great orbital shuttle, plus the space station parts are a lot of fun to play with. The orbital tug, especially, is a fine piece of work -- a near perfect tool for its intended job. I suspect, however, that the KSO requirement has sadly put many folks off. I may re-design the challenge at some point with all stock vehicles.

Regardless, I did play my scenario through, start to finish, and had quite a bit of fun with it. Here is a photo album for future reference. A word of caution: it includes spoilers for the scenario.
